content: There are so many tragedies to Iraq. More than successes will ever make up for. To ALL those that are and have bravly served. I appologies to you for a screwed up mess my nation has gotten you in to from day 1. Try to hang in there. Think of your loved ones. Think of the great times back home you will have when you return. Remember the little things you did that you enjoyed doing and know that one day you will be doing them again.

content: A guy in my company committed suicide in Iraq during the first Gulf war. the night before we redeployed to saudi. Put his rifle on burst to do it. I sent years trying to figure that one out.. finally just gave up.. I guess some things just weren't meant to make sense.

What makes sense is the PL, 1SG, and PSG need to be court-martialed for derelection of duty, criminal negligence...etc There is no way "Captain America" woke up one day and decided to murder some of battle buddies for the hell of it. content: The news agencies indicate that it happened at a combat stress clinic, so one can only guess that there were some problems that the Soldier was dealing with. If the chain of command sent him there, they could hardly be faulted, as that is what combat stress is there for. It almost makes you want to rethink the wisdom of everyone walking around on the huge basecamps with weapons and ammo at all times.
reply: The news agencies indicate that it happened at a combat stress clinic, so one can only guess that there were some problems that the Soldier was dealing with. title: U.S. service member kills 4 fellow troops in Iraq

content: quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: BS!! What makes sense is the PL, 1SG, and PSG need to be court-martialed for derelection of duty, criminal negligence...etc There is no way "Captain America" woke up one day and decided to murder some of battle buddies for the hell of it. His chain of command is completely responsible for this, its their fault this moron snapped and killed men.. He was at a Combat Stress Clinic so his Chain of Command likley had an idea he was having some issues. Unless a Doctor says he's too dangerous, all Soldiers in Iraq are REQUIRED to be armed 24/7. Thats why you see the Joe's with Mags in pouches even at the Messhall & PX. Frankly I dont know the facts here, so wouldnt begin to think the CoC needs to be Court Martialed yet, if at all. And "Captain America" May have been in REAL mental distress, or may have been pulling a Hassan Akbar/Alberto Martinez. We dont know yet

content: US involvement in Iraq is, as it was in Vietnam, an exercise in futility. Sorry but anyone who can't see that is either ignorant or dishonest. If we kept 500,000 US troops in Iraq, ran it as a police state and spent a BILLION $ per week and did that indefinitely then MAYBE we might eventually "succeed". We all know that's NOT going to happen. Indeed, we will soon be watching a spectacle on Capitol Hill as the Obama Administration pleads for BILLIONS more in taxpayer dollars to keep the whole circus going. Its deja vu all over again, 1974-1975, Gerald Ford trying to make the case that if we just give our "allies" in Vietnam (Iraq this time) more time and money, we will eventually "win" the "war".
reply: US involvement in Iraq is, as it was in Vietnam, an exercise in futility. Sorry but anyone who can't see that is either ignorant or dishonest. If we kept 500,000 US troops in Iraq, ran it as a police state and spent a BILLION $ per week and did that indefinitely then MAYBE we might eventually "succeed". content: quote: Originally posted by godawgz: A guy in my company committed suicide in Iraq during the first Gulf war. the night before we redeployed to saudi. Put his rifle on burst to do it. I sent years trying to figure that one out.. finally just gave up.. I guess some things just weren't meant to make sense. It doesn't take a war in the military. A trainee on the rifle range put the muzzle in his mouth and blew his brains out. Our senior Drill had the task of retreaving his helmet with his winter hat and brains still inside. The troop displayed no discipline problems or training difficulties and left no written reason why. War inviroment or not...it's sad.
quote: Originally posted by godawgz: A guy in my company committed suicide in Iraq during the first Gulf war. the night before we redeployed to saudi. Put his rifle on burst to do it. War inviroment or not...it's sad.

content: This guy had clearly lost all perspective and all hope, and quite literally, his mind. It doesn't excuse his behavior, but it's still sad. The first question they ask you when you check in at Combat Mental Health in country is, "Are you thinking of hurting yourself or others?" Guess he didn't make it past that. . . Be prepared for more suicide prevention awareness briefings, with a new segment on homicide prevention. War is hell. Anyone who says different is selling something.
reply: This guy had clearly lost all perspective and all hope, and quite literally, his mind. It doesn't excuse his behavior, but it's still sad. The first question they ask you when you check in at Combat Mental Health in country is, "Are you thinking of hurting yourself or others?" Guess he didn't make it past that. . . Be prepared for more suicide prevention awareness briefings, with a new segment on homicide prevention. War is hell. Anyone who says different is selling something.

NBC is claiming this soldier killed himself? How could he have killed himself if he is in custody? Either NBC got it wrong or the military is holding an innocent person. Talk about confusing. content: quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: BS!! What makes sense is the PL, 1SG, and PSG need to be court-martialed for derelection of duty, criminal negligence...etc There is no way "Captain America" woke up one day and decided to murder some of battle buddies for the hell of it. His chain of command is completely responsible for this, its their fault this moron snapped and killed men.. Irwin: "It's their fault this moron snapped and killed men"? An interesting logic on your part. Suppose he had a mental problem, nothing to do with the war, his assignment, his duties, his performance, etc. Many of us have heard of similar incidents, probably not as serious as this one, seemingly without justification and often without warning. However, long before you know the facts, you want to hang those in his immediate chain of command. Sorry, but I prefer to see him held accountable for his actions and allow the system (UCMJ/mental health evaluation/etc) to determine cause and responsibility. Jack

content: quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: BS!! What makes sense is the PL, 1SG, and PSG need to be court-martialed for derelection of duty, criminal negligence...etc There is no way "Captain America" woke up one day and decided to murder some of battle buddies for the hell of it. His chain of command is completely responsible for this, its their fault this moron snapped and killed men.. What is your experience as a PL, 1SG, or PSG in a combat zone? I have been been a PL over there, and I can tell you that my Soldiers welfare was my number one priority. Without them in the right mental state our mission wasn't going to be accomplished. There is only so much we can do, and often a person can internalize issues and seem just fine. A Soldier in another company in my battalion killed himself there and nobody saw it coming.

content: quote: Originally posted by ss_287: "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30678715/" NBC: ‘Stressed out’ soldier kills self after attack at Baghdad’s Camp Liberty BAGHDAD - A U.S. service member opened fire on fellow members of the military, killing four and wounding several others, at the main U.S. base in Baghdad, officials told NBC News on Monday. NBC is claiming this soldier killed himself? How could he have killed himself if he is in custody? Either NBC got it wrong or the military is holding an innocent person. Talk about confusing. Todays politics remind me of an old saying. - "Ideas are more powerful than guns. We would not let our enemies have guns, why should we let them have ideas?" - Joseph Stalin
quote: Originally posted by ss_287: "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30678715/" NBC: ‘Stressed out’ soldier kills self after attack at Baghdad’s Camp Liberty BAGHDAD - A U.S. service member opened fire on fellow members of the military, killing four and wounding several others, at the main U.S. base in Baghdad, officials told NBC News on Monday.

content: quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: BS!! What makes sense is the PL, 1SG, and PSG need to be court-martialed for derelection of duty, criminal negligence...etc There is no way "Captain America" woke up one day and decided to murder some of battle buddies for the hell of it. His chain of command is completely responsible for this, its their fault this moron snapped and killed men.. Irwin: "It's their fault this moron snapped and killed men"? An interesting logic on your part. Suppose he had a mental problem, nothing to do with the war, his assignment, his duties, his performance, etc. Many of us have heard of similar incidents, probably not as serious as this one, seemingly without justification and often without warning. However, long before you know the facts, you want to hang those in his immediate chain of command. Sorry, but I prefer to see him held accountable for his actions and allow the system (UCMJ/mental health evaluation/etc) to determine cause and responsibility. Jack

content: There are so many tragedies to Iraq. More than successes will ever make up for. To ALL those that are and have bravly served. I appologies to you for a screwed up mess my nation has gotten you in to from day 1. Try to hang in there. Think of your loved ones. Think of the great times back home you will have when you return. Remember the little things you did that you enjoyed doing and know that one day you will be doing them again.

content: A guy in my company committed suicide in Iraq during the first Gulf war. the night before we redeployed to saudi. Put his rifle on burst to do it. I sent years trying to figure that one out.. finally just gave up.. I guess some things just weren't meant to make sense.

content: The news agencies indicate that it happened at a combat stress clinic, so one can only guess that there were some problems that the Soldier was dealing with. If the chain of command sent him there, they could hardly be faulted, as that is what combat stress is there for. It almost makes you want to rethink the wisdom of everyone walking around on the huge basecamps with weapons and ammo at all times.
reply: The news agencies indicate that it happened at a combat stress clinic, so one can only guess that there were some problems that the Soldier was dealing with. content: quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: BS!! What makes sense is the PL, 1SG, and PSG need to be court-martialed for derelection of duty, criminal negligence...etc There is no way "Captain America" woke up one day and decided to murder some of battle buddies for the hell of it. His chain of command is completely responsible for this, its their fault this moron snapped and killed men.. He was at a Combat Stress Clinic so his Chain of Command likley had an idea he was having some issues. Unless a Doctor says he's too dangerous, all Soldiers in Iraq are REQUIRED to be armed 24/7. Thats why you see the Joe's with Mags in pouches even at the Messhall & PX. Frankly I dont know the facts here, so wouldnt begin to think the CoC needs to be Court Martialed yet, if at all. And "Captain America" May have been in REAL mental distress, or may have been pulling a Hassan Akbar/Alberto Martinez. We dont know yet

content: US involvement in Iraq is, as it was in Vietnam, an exercise in futility. Sorry but anyone who can't see that is either ignorant or dishonest. If we kept 500,000 US troops in Iraq, ran it as a police state and spent a BILLION $ per week and did that indefinitely then MAYBE we might eventually "succeed". We all know that's NOT going to happen. Indeed, we will soon be watching a spectacle on Capitol Hill as the Obama Administration pleads for BILLIONS more in taxpayer dollars to keep the whole circus going. Its deja vu all over again, 1974-1975, Gerald Ford trying to make the case that if we just give our "allies" in Vietnam (Iraq this time) more time and money, we will eventually "win" the "war".
reply: US involvement in Iraq is, as it was in Vietnam, an exercise in futility. Sorry but anyone who can't see that is either ignorant or dishonest. If we kept 500,000 US troops in Iraq, ran it as a police state and spent a BILLION $ per week and did that indefinitely then MAYBE we might eventually "succeed". We all know that's NOT going to happen. content: quote: Originally posted by godawgz: A guy in my company committed suicide in Iraq during the first Gulf war. the night before we redeployed to saudi. Put his rifle on burst to do it. I sent years trying to figure that one out.. finally just gave up.. I guess some things just weren't meant to make sense. It doesn't take a war in the military. A trainee on the rifle range put the muzzle in his mouth and blew his brains out. Our senior Drill had the task of retreaving his helmet with his winter hat and brains still inside. The troop displayed no discipline problems or training difficulties and left no written reason why. War inviroment or not...it's sad.
quote: Originally posted by godawgz: A guy in my company committed suicide in Iraq during the first Gulf war. the night before we redeployed to saudi. Put his rifle on burst to do it. War inviroment or not...it's sad.

content: This guy had clearly lost all perspective and all hope, and quite literally, his mind. It doesn't excuse his behavior, but it's still sad. The first question they ask you when you check in at Combat Mental Health in country is, "Are you thinking of hurting yourself or others?" Guess he didn't make it past that. . . Be prepared for more suicide prevention awareness briefings, with a new segment on homicide prevention. War is hell. Anyone who says different is selling something.
